Next academic year in sport

04/10/2022

Image by

By Gracie Daw

When preparing for the new academic year, most tend to do a stationery shop, or perhaps buy a new bag which will fit all the late night library essentials. But for some, the new academic year brings with it a new season of sport. So here is a rundown of all the big sporting events over the next academic year. Whether you are a spectator, competitor or potential Nouse Sport reporter, here are the things to look out for.

2 October
London Marathon. For a third year in a row, the London Marathon has been moved from its normal April date. Mo Farah is set to compete in the elite field. Thousands of pounds will also be raised for charity.

8 October- 12 November
Womenâ€™s Rugby Union World Cup. Postponed from 2021, the womenâ€™s rugby world cup is happening in New Zealand in October and November this year.

15 October
Deontay Wilder v Robert Helenius. Wilder makes his return to the ring in his first fight since Fury v Wilder 3. Wilder will be looking to make a statement against the Finnish Helenius. He has stated that he wants to fight Oleksander Usyk, Anthony Joshua and Andy Ruiz Jr after Helenius.

15 October- 19 November
Menâ€™s, Womenâ€™s and Wheelchair rugby league world cups are being hosted in England, postponed from last year, with some games being played in York.

16 October- 13 November
ICC Menâ€™s T20 Cricket World Cup, Australia, 2022. The sportâ€™s most popular format will have its world cup this Autumn. England have looked good against Pakistan in their warm-up matches, with some pundits classing them as the favourites.

12- 20 November
UK Snooker Championship 2022. Hosted in York at the Barbican, the best snooker players in the world will battle it out to win the first major of the snooker season. Itâ€™s definitely worth a visit.

20 November
Final F1 Grand Prix of the season held in Abu Dhabi. The title will most likely be won by this stage but it is important to note that this will be Sebastian Vettelâ€™s last race in F1.

20 November- 18 December
Menâ€™s football world cup. One of the biggest sporting events in the world is happening this year in Qatar. Games will likely be shown in campus bars, meaning that students can get together and watch with their friends. Read some previous Nouse Sport articles about this event on our website or keep an eye out for upcoming articles this term.

15- 19 December
Olympia Horse show held annually in London. Multiple equestrian competitions and shows such as showjumping championships, puissance and displays.

15 December- 3rd January 2023
World Darts Championship. The biggest tournament in darts will be back at Ally Pally for another year. More fancy dress, more chanting and maybe even some world class darts. Itâ€™s an event not to be missed.

14 February- 18 March
Rugby Union Six Nations. France will be aiming to defend their title that they brilliantly won this year. â€˜Super Saturdayâ€™, the day that all of the final matches take place, will be on 18 March, with England playing Ireland on the final day.

Likely March 2023
College Varsity. University of York colleges compete against Durham University colleges in Varsity. Each college team will take part in qualifiers to decide whether they compete against a Durham college, with the top two colleges in each sport progressing. York won in 2022, can we retain the title next year? This is an excellent opportunity for those who take part in college sport and this year will be held in Durham.

Likely April/May 2023
Roses 2023. Roses is the biggest inter-university sports competition in Europe and is taken very seriously by those at York. It will be hosted in York this year which means home advantage both due to crowd support and the fact that those of us from York will not have to sleep on the floors of lecture theatres! It is named after the War of the Roses, a series of battles in the fifteenth century between the House of York and the House of Lancaster. The main thing to remember is that Roses are White! It was last hosted by York in its full capacity in 2019, given that it was cancelled in 2020 and replaced by Roses Unlocked in 2021, which took place between both York and Lancaster campuses. In 2022, there were 43 sports competing meaning there is something for every-one to compete in or support from the sidelines.

16 June- 31st July
Men and womenâ€™s Ashes series in the UK. The Ashes returns this summer with both the menâ€™s and womenâ€™s series running concurrently this summer. The Aussie men beat England 4-0 in the last series, Ben Stokesâ€™ team will be eager to avenge this embarrassing defeat.

1- 23 July
Tour de France. Cyclingâ€™s most famous event will return once again. The worldâ€™s best riders will compete for the coveted yellow jersey.

2- 16 July
Wimbledon 2023. Strawberries and cream will return to south west London this summer. Novak Djokovic won his seventh Wimbledon last year. Heâ€™ll be looking to match the recently retired Federerâ€™s record tally of eight Wimbledon titles.

15- 16 July
International Quidditch Association World Cup. Yes, it does exist.

16- 23 July
The 151st Open Championship held at Royal Liverpool Golf Club, Hoylake, Wirral. â€˜Golf â€™s Original Championshipâ€™ will take place again in 2023, this year at Royal Liverpool. Rory McIlroy won last time The Open was held here, in 2014.

20 July- 20 August
Womenâ€™s Football World Cup in Australia and New Zealand. After their triumph in the Euros, Englandâ€™s women will be aiming for more glory on the other side of the globe as they head down under this summer for a month of top-level womenâ€™s football.
